thought.author: Larry Tesler
thought.description: How would modern user interfaces look like without copy & paste? Today's issue of #ThoughtsOnProgramming features Larry Tesler, who invented the cut, copy and paste commands during his time at Xerox PARC.
thought.quote: You cannot reduce the complexity of a given task beyond a certain point. Once you've reached that point, you can only shift the burden around.

thought.author: Martin Fowler
thought.description: In a professional environment, the ratio of time spent reading versus writing code is about 10 to 1. Producing clean, comprehensive and maintainable code is of utmost importance and leads to increased team effectiveness. Here's nice quote from Thought Works Martin Fowler which sums it up quite nicely.
thought.quote: Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.

thought.author: Andy Hunt
thought.description: Unless you fancy shipping faulty software, one should apply appropriate testing techniques, ideally, let your tests drive implementation. Today's issue of #ThoughtsOnProgramming features Andy Hunt, author of the "The Pragmatic Programmer", a timeless introduction on how to contribute maintainable code on teams.
thought.quote: No one in the brief history of computing has ever written a piece of perfect software. It's unlikely that you'll be the first.
